item.title: N-Dimensional Tourists: Conflict Resolution
item.description: About these rules These rules are part of the N-Dimensional Tourists ruleset. Specifically, this entry describes a mechanism to resolve Conflicts between two parties or more during a role-playing game. This mechanism is designed to be abstract and generic – it works just as well with a pirate crew boarding a merchan ship as with two Formula 1 pilots racing each other or three political parties attempting to win or steal the elections.

item.title: Space·Time Deck: The Suit of Out There
item.description: Well, after the Triumphs and four suits (Paper, Rock, Blade, Serpent), it is time to conclude the Space·Time Deck with its last suit: the Suit of Out There (also known as Suit of Spock)! Out There symbolizes: imagination; dream confusing dream and reality. The cards: Ruler Dragon Treasure Soldier Builder Seeker Lover Servant Home Foot (blank, customizable) Teddy bear (blank, customizable) Credits Cards David Teller.

item.title: Space·Time Deck: The Suit of Serpents
item.description: Did you think the Space·Time Deck was done after the Triumphs; the Suit of Paper; the Suit of Rock; the Suit of Blade? Were it only that it were so simple! Here’s the fourth suit: the Suit of Serpents. Serpents traditionally symbolize: guardians or enablers of forbidden knowledge or power; threats; survival. The cards: Ruler Dragon Treasure Soldier Builder Seeker Lover Servant Home Foot (blank, customizable) Teddy bear (blank, customizable) Credits Cards David Teller.

item.title: Conflict Resolution With the Space·Time Deck
item.description: Most Role-Playing Games resolve conflicts with dice. But since we have a Space·Time Deck at hand (or any other kind of Tarot-like Deck), let’s see if we can use it to bring about a different manner of resolving conflicts. About Conflicts A Conflict is a scene in which two parties or more have agendas, which cannot be fulfilled simultaneously. In most role-playing games, the most common form of conflict is the combat, but that is by no mean the only form possible: conflict could be car races, social wit, political campaigns, chess, battlefield strategy, attempting to ruin your opponent’s reputation or fortune, popularity contests, football matches, etc.

item.title: Improvising with the Space·Time Deck: V. Hello, you gorgeous!
item.description: This is an extract from the Plotonomicon. Note that we have just changed the picture from The old picture (The Slaughter of the Innocents) one was considered too violent – while both are museum pieces, the first one depicts mass murder of children, and was thus discarded as not-safe-for-children’s-hands. This new version gets rid of almost all violence, and offers much more symbolism, hence much more freedom of improv.
